questions.question_text:
A company has hired a new IT firm to manage its network switches and routers. The firm is geographically separated from the company and will need to able to securely access the devices.
Which of the following will provide the ability to access these devices?

discussion.content: SSH is the only secure connection none of the others offer a secure connection by themselves

Selected Answer: B
it provides a secure and encrypted method for remote access to servers and systems

Selected Answer: B
Security access - SSH

Selected Answer: B
VNC and RDP are not for managing routers/switches.
Telnet is in clear text thus not secure

SSH is the only secure option thus the correct choice.
Answer is A:. Telnet is for access to the devices. SSH is for the security. For a very secure connection, you combine both. Telnet in with SSH encryption

comments.content: but the answer doesn't say chose two SSH is the only clear answer or you're just trolling.
Stop it. Get some help. Ans is SSH clearly.

discussion.content: VNC server : It is a graphical desktop sharing system that allows a user to remotely control the desktop of a remote computer (running VNC Server) from your device, and it transmits the keyboard and mouse or touch events to VNC Server, so that once you are connected, you have control over the computer you've accessed.
This is about the hundredth time Ann has experienced technical problems. The company would be better off firing her.

comments.content: nah fr im tired of seeing ANN lol

discussion.content:
Example of this is when you use Starbucks wifi. You are connected once you select the SSID but in order to access the internet you need to open a browser and agree to their internet guidelines. 
B is correct.

The best course of action in this scenario would be B. Ask Ann to open a browser and watch for a redirect page.The WiFi network ConnectMe appears as unsecured, which suggests it might be a public WiFi network. Many public WiFi networks require users to agree to terms of service or enter login credentials on a web page before they can access the internet. This is known as a captive portal. If Ann opens a browser, she may be redirected to such a page where she can gain full internet access, allowing her to retrieve her corporate email.

comments.content: that's what I have thought too, the answer should be asking ann to connect to a VPN so no one could hack her data in a public place.

discussion.content: This whole question infuriates me. How is the tech still employed after recommending that she put her device, personal and corporate data at risk by messing with a compromised connection. That's like getting a call after someone that visited a website that is clearly harboring malware and telling them to click around just to make sure.
She's at Maccas for a munch, so you need to go through their redirection page on the internet to access the internet properly.

comments.content: it may not be C, you're assuming she has a hardwire connection at home or how to use it. she may be naïve

discussion.content: The answer is C because the WI-Fi she connect to is unsecure and connect to your house internet is more secure.
The answer is C because the WI-Fi she connect to is in secure and connect to your house internet is more secure.

She is either connecting to a wireless set up by someone with malicious intent which has a proxy set up to redirect the page OR she is connecting to a public Wi-Fi (like in a library or a train station) where after you connect, you would need to agree to some policies before receiving access to the network. I assume it's the latter and it would make sense this way.

choices.A: Remote into Ann's system and restart the wireless adapter
choices.D: Direct Ann to run an antivirus program on her laptop
choices.B: Ask Ann to open a browser and watch for a redirect page

questions.question_text:
Ann, a user, calls the help desk regarding an issue on her laptop. While working remotely, she appears to be connecting to WiFi but is unable to retrieve her corporate email. The wireless name is listed as `ConnectMe` and appears as unsecure.
Which of the following should the help desk perform to fix the issue?

discussion.content: B is correct. The desktop get special static IP from DHCP Reservation. (Manually sign static IP on PC is wrong operation.as it will cause duplicate IP release by DHCP).The laptop must have the same special static IP manually, that will cause the IP Conflict problem when connect to the network.To solve the problem.The First STEP is to set the laptop to use DHCP. The 2nd step is to change DHCP Server setting. So the answer is B.
use the DHCP reservation as the user needs a "specifically allocated address for the software. The answer is B.

If the laptop is new and the desktop is old and the user needs a static configuration then it is the new laptop that needs the static configuration, which means the desktop needs to lose it's static config so there is no longer a conflict with the laptop.

Selected Answer: C
DHCP will assign a random address, but the application needs a specific address, the correct answer is C

Selected Answer: B
B is the right answer

Selected Answer: C
It is C.

I supposed both the Laptop and the old desktop have the "specifically allocated address", but there are 2 identical "specifically allocated address" causing IP conflicts.

If we remove the "specifically allocated address" from old desktop, there will be only ONE "specifically allocated address" left on the laptop, and making it able to log in to specialized software again.

I think it is not B,
as the DHCP allocates the dynamic IP address, which is totally random and it is unlikely a "specifically allocated address".

Hope that makes sense

Selected Answer: C
I think it's C. Remove the static IP configuration from the desktop.

The question says the software "requires a specifically allocated (IP) address" to connect to the software and it seems like the old desktop has been assigned that specific static IP address. Since the desktop is old and probably being replaced by the new laptop, it should be configured to use DHCP instead so that the new laptop can be assigned that specific IP address as it will be used more often by the user.

questions.question_text:
A user turns on a new laptop and attempts to log in to specialized software, but receives a message stating that the address is already in use. The user logs on to the old desktop and receives the same message. A technician checks the account and sees a comment that the user requires a specifically allocated address before connecting to the software.
Which of the following should the technician do to MOST likely resolve the issue?

choices.C: Remove the static IP configuration from the desktop.
choices.D: Replace the network card in the laptop, as it may be defective.
choices.A: Bridge the LAN connection between the laptop and the desktop.
choices.B: Set the laptop configuration to DHCP to prevent conflicts.
